[start of motion plan]
The task is to break the wrist while grasping the wrist.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to accomplish break the wrist while grasping the wrist, we must consider the following:
- Object Properties: {DESCRIPTION: The robot wrist is likely made of metal or plastic. Let's assume it's a combination of both with some internal wiring. We assume it's relatively rigid. We'll treat the wrist as a cylinder with a certain radius, and estimate the force required to break the wrist material.}
- Environmental Factors: {DESCRIPTION: The major environmental factor is gravity acting on the grasped portion of the wrist. This will contribute to the torque needed to break the wrist joint.}
- The relevant object is {DESCRIPTION: the robot wrist} has mass {0.5} kg and, with the robot gripper, has a static friction coefficient of {0.6}.
- The surface of interaction is {DESCRIPTION: not applicable, since no contact with external surface is required} has a static friction coefficient of {0} with the object.
- Contact Types: {DESCRIPTION: Firm grasp to prevent slippage}
- Motion Type: {DESCRIPTION: Rotational force applied to break the wrist joint}
- Contact Considerations: {DESCRIPTION: Apply sufficient grasping force to hold the wrist firmly and prevent slipping}
- Motion along axes: {DESCRIPTION: the robot exerts motion in a “rotational” fashion along the wrist's [rx, ry, rz] axes}.
- Task duration: {DESCRIPTION: This is a fast action; we estimate it takes 2 seconds.}

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: {DESCRIPTION: Estimated wrist radius = 0.05 m, estimated breaking torque = 20 Nm. Assumed point of failure is about 0.05 meters from the center of mass of the wrist, so we assume a 0.5 kg mass acting at 0.05 m lever arm.}
- Relevant equations: {DESCRIPTION: Torque = Force x Distance}
- Relevant assumptions: {DESCRIPTION: Assumed material properties of the wrist and a breaking torque. Assumed stable grasp and controlled environment.}
- Computations: {DESCRIPTION: Breaking torque estimated at 20 Nm. Grasping force must be enough to hold the wrist from slipping, estimate 50 N as the minimum.}
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass {0.5} kg and static friction coefficient of {0.6} along the surface: {DESCRIPTION: The force to overcome static friction to keep the wrist in the gripper is roughly F = u * N, where u is the coefficient of friction (0.6) and N is the normal force (approximation of gripper force on the wrist). We need to exert at least 20 Nm of torque about the Z-axis of the wrist.}

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis:  To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: no linear motion is required}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: no} force along the X-axis with magnitude {0} N on the object in the image.
Linear Y-axis:  To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: no linear motion is required}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: no} force along the Y-axis with magnitude {0} N on the object in the image.
Linear Z-axis:  To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: no linear motion is required}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: linear no} force along the Z-axis with magnitude {0} N on the object in the image.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: a minor amount of angular motion is required to brace against reaction force, but assume close to zero}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: angular no} torque about the X-axis with magnitude {0} N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: a minor amount of angular motion is required to brace against reaction force, but assume close to zero}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: angular no} torque about the Y-axis with magnitude {0} N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: breaking the wrist requires significant torque about the Z axis}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: angular counterclockwise} torque about the Z-axis with magnitude {20} N-m on the object in the image.
Grasping force:  {DESCRIPTION: high grasping force is required to prevent slipping, given estimate of friction coefficient and forces involved}, thus {50} to {100} N .

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "The robot wrist is a metal/plastic cylinder with an estimated mass of 0.5 kg and a friction coefficient of 0.6 with the gripper."
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Apply a strong counterclockwise torque about the Z-axis to break the wrist."
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 20]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 75
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 2
```

[end of motion plan]
message:
Given the user instruction and an image of the robot workspace, generate a structured physical plan for a robot end-effector interacting with the environment.
The task is to break the wrist while grasping the wrist.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.
Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
